proposals.reasoning: I know I’m good, and Diana has been cautious about self-inclusion and open to scrutiny, which is more town-leaning. Multiple players (Diana, Eve, and myself) have suggested Charlie + Diana as a cleaner first read, while Bob pushing a team including himself has drawn consistent suspicion. Alice also preferred avoiding herself and Eve on the first mission. This team both maximizes our chance of a success and gives the table a relatively clean information point for later deductions.

votes.comment: This matches my earlier preference to keep both myself and Eve off the first mission, and it gives us a clean info point without putting extra heat on me.
Charlie+Diana avoids the early-suspect pairings and fits the consensus for a cleaner first read, so I’m fine backing this as a safe opener.
I know I’m good, Diana feels more cautious/transparent than Bob, and this team aligns with multiple players’ preference for a low-sus first mission that gives clean info.
I trust myself, and Charlie feels more cautious and less self‑pushing than Bob. This is a cleaner, lower‑risk first mission than including Bob right now.
No evil on the team, so a likely clean success would give Charlie and Diana too much early trust.

discussion.content: For the first mission I’d rather see two people who haven’t really drawn any heat yet—something like Bob and Diana feels safest to me. I don’t love putting either myself or Eve on this one so early, since that just gives evil an easy place to hide if it fails.

I’m okay with Bob and Diana for a first mission too—it keeps the people who’ve been doing the early steering off the team and gives us a cleaner signal. If it fails, we get a lot of info without immediately locking in bad assumptions about the loudest voices.
Bob + Diana is a fine low‑info first team, but Bob pushing a team that includes himself this early makes me a bit wary—if we do go with it, we should scrutinize reactions hard if it fails.

I’m okay being on the first team, but I share a bit of Charlie’s hesitation about Bob pushing himself—if we want a cleaner read, I’d slightly prefer something like me + Charlie, or Bob + me with everyone agreeing we treat a fail as serious suspicion on Bob.

I’m a little uneasy with Bob pushing a team that includes himself this early, so I’d rather see something like Diana + Charlie as a cleaner first read. If we do go with Bob + Diana anyway, I think we should all agree a fail points much more strongly at Bob.

proposals.reasoning: I know I’m good, so I’m locking myself in. I’m *not* auto‑reusing the Charlie–Diana core, because if Charlie is evil, keeping him on every mission gives him repeated chances to sabotage while looking safe from the first clean result. By excluding Charlie this round, we directly test a completely new trio relative to Mission 1 and force evil (if on this team) to reveal themselves earlier. Between the remaining players, Bob and Alice are both untested and were the main candidates everyone was circling around; putting them together with me gives maximum information: if this mission passes clean, it strongly points suspicion toward Charlie/Eve; if it fails, we’ll know at least one of Bob/Alice is evil and can use votes and reactions to refine that. This balances a real shot at success with high informational value, instead of just trusting the previous leader’s preferred extension of the original core.

votes.comment: I like testing a new trio without Charlie; this gives us fresh info while still having a plausible chance to succeed.
Alice is untrustworthy here; I’d rather keep her off a small 3‑person team this early.
I know I’m good and helped pass Mission 1; excluding me for a full set of mostly untested players is too risky compared to keeping at least part of the proven core.
I know I’m good, and this tests both Alice and Bob while keeping Charlie off for a round; it’s a reasonable balance of success chance and information gain.
Alice is on the team so evil is represented; this setup gives us a good chance to sabotage while keeping suspicion spread across the new trio.

discussion.content: Given how clean that first mission was, I’m a bit wary of sending the exact same core again—I'd rather see a mix like me, Bob, and one of Charlie/Diana so we’re not blindly trusting an untested pair.

I’d actually lean toward keeping the Charlie–Diana core for now and just add one new person, rather than breaking up the only pair we’ve seen succeed. If we go with three, something like Charlie, Diana, and one of me/Alice seems safer than rebuilding from scratch.

I like keeping the Charlie–Diana core for now, but we definitely need new info, so I’d propose adding Alice this round and see how that mix behaves. If that mission stays clean, we’ll have a much clearer picture going forward.

I’m okay re-using the Charlie–Diana core for now, but I’d rather add Bob than Alice this time so we aren’t just following Charlie’s suggestion without any counterweight. If Charlie’s evil, he has every reason to pull Alice in right now.

I get Diana’s concern about just rubber‑stamping Charlie’s suggestion, but I still slightly prefer adding Alice to the Charlie–Diana core this round, because if that team stays clean it gives us a much stronger info baseline than constantly reshuffling everything. If people really hate that, I’d at least keep one of Charlie/Diana and pair them with Alice and someone new, rather than breaking up both of them at once.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Charlie and Diana succeeded cleanly, suggesting Charlie is relatively trustworthy so far. Choosing Charlie plus me (Eve) avoids the contentious Alice/Bob combination, keeps a previously safe anchor in Charlie, and tests a new pairing without reusing the exact team that just produced a fail.

discussion.content: I still don’t like how Mission 2 went, so I’d rather avoid repeating that exact team—between Diana and Bob there’s almost certainly at least one evil. For this next mission I’d be more comfortable with something like Charlie plus Eve, since both are still relatively untested.

proposals.reasoning: This team aligns with the emerging consensus split: everyone accepts that exactly one of Charlie/Eve is bad and one of Alice/Bob/Diana is bad, so Diana–Alice–Eve is a ‘fresh’ combination that avoids repeating either prior failing team exactly, while fitting both Diana’s and Eve’s stated preference for testing this trio. It keeps Bob off after the failed 3‑player mission, doesn’t automatically clear Charlie as good, and should be broadly acceptable to multiple players as a reasonable experimental lineup given the current theories.

evil_discussion.content: If I had to shoot right now, I’d go for Diana as Merlin: she keeps pairing with Alice while repeatedly stressing “don’t clear us off clean missions,” which feels like someone who *knows* the pair is good but is deliberately keeping paranoia alive. Alice feels like my backup pick—she’s very comfortable anchoring every mission but her tone is more “confident leader” than “info-leaking Merlin,” whereas Diana’s meta‑talk about how evil!Alice would behave and how a fail could’ve been used to muddy things reads a lot more like quiet, protective Merlin work.

I’m with you that Diana pings the hardest for Merlin: the way she keeps doubling down on the Alice–Diana core while *also* repeatedly cautioning “don’t hard-clear us off clean missions” feels like someone who knows they’re both good and is managing town paranoia instead of genuinely solving. Alice’s confidence and willingness to anchor every mission could be Merlin, but it’s also very on‑brand for her as either alignment, whereas Diana’s specific meta‑talk about how evil!Alice would have played Mission 2 sounds more like informed analysis than guesswork. Bob, by contrast, mostly just echoes “proven pair” logic and doesn’t show the same level of subtle steering, so I’d rank them Diana > Alice >>> Bob.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Diana consistently supports the Alice–Diana core while carefully warning others not to fully clear them, which fits a Merlin who knows they’re both good but wants to maintain healthy paranoia. From my perspective I know at least one of Bob/Eve has to be evil, so for this 2-person team I’d really prefer something like me + Alice or me + Charlie and keep both Bob and Eve off for now.

Given how Mission 2 went, I agree I should stay off this one, so I’d like to see a team from {Alice, Charlie, Diana} and keep both Bob and me out for a cleaner signal. Between those, Alice + Charlie feels like a reasonable low-conflict pair.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Bob and Diana succeeded, so that pair is proven clean as a duo. Mission 2 (Bob, Diana, Eve) then failed, which means the only way to reconcile a clean Mission 1 and a failed Mission 2 is that Eve is evil and Diana is good (if Diana were evil, Mission 1 would have failed). That confirms Diana as good and strongly implicates Eve as evil. Mission 3 (Alice, Charlie) failed with exactly one fail card, so exactly one of Alice or Charlie is evil. Since we know the two evil players are Eve and exactly one of {Alice, Charlie}, the only fully good trios that include me are {Bob, Diana, Alice} if Alice is good or {Bob, Diana, Charlie} if Charlie is good. Both are structurally valid, but Alice also led the failed Mission 3 and has only appeared on a failing team, while Charlie at least aligns with the clean M1 core plus a single new add. Given that, Bob–Diana–Charlie is the highest-probability all-good team based on the mission results and role constraints.

votes.comment: I don’t buy that Bob–Diana are mechanically cleared just because M1 was clean; an evil can pass an early 2p mission. Locking that pair in after they produced a fail on M2 feels like tunneled logic, and I’d rather see a team that breaks up that duo instead of assuming the third seat is always the problem.

Given the constraints we know exactly one evil is in {B,D,E} and one in {A,C}. B–D–C avoids both players who have only appeared on failing teams (E and A) and matches the clean M1 core plus a single new add. It’s not guaranteed, but it’s the highest-consensus, least-bad option right now.

Best alignment with mission info: M1’s Bob–Diana was clean, M2 implicates Eve, and M3 shows exactly one of Alice/Charlie is bad; this team is the only plausible all-good trio that avoids both Eve and the Alice–Charlie conflict while still using the proven M1 core.

Given all consistent evil-pair combinations and knowing I’m good, this team is only fully good in the specific case where Eve and Alice are both evil. In the three other plausible setups, either Bob or Charlie (or both) are evil and on this team. With evil already at 2 mission wins, that risk is too high to approve.

This locks in the Bob–Diana core again and sends a fully untested trio without me or Alice, which feels too convenient if the fail on M2 wasn’t as simple as ‘blame the new addition’; I’d rather see a team that changes the core, like swapping one of Bob/Diana out.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Bob and Diana was clean, and the only change on Mission 2’s fail was adding Eve, while Mission 3’s fail implicates at least one of Alice/Charlie. Since we have to include someone from that last pair, I’ll keep the proven-success core of Bob–Diana and add myself as the least-contested option so far. This avoids both players who’ve only appeared on failed missions (Alice and Eve together) while still being consistent with all known results.

votes.comment: This keeps the Bob–Diana pair together despite them giving both a success and a fail; I’d rather see a team that breaks that core instead of assuming the third seat was always the problem.

Given mission results, the only consistent evil pairs from my perspective are (A,E), (E,C), (A,D), (D,C). This team B–C–D is fully good only in the (A,E) case; in the other three, it contains at least one evil (C and/or D), so it looks too risky to send at 1–2 down.
Fits the clean M1 core, excludes both players who’ve only been on failing teams, and I’ve already argued this trio looks best given the results so far.

Logic says exactly one evil in {B,D,E} and one in {A,C}. Eve’s push to include herself plus Alice’s parallel push to break the Bob–Diana core both fit the A+E evil pairing, which makes Bob–Charlie–Diana the all-good team.

I’m still not comfortable locking in the Bob–Diana core that’s already produced one fail; this is the same trio idea we just turned down, and I’d rather see the composition actually change instead of doubling down on a possibly poisoned pair.

proposals.reasoning: I know I’m good, so the question is where the two evils sit among Bob/Eve and Alice/Charlie. From the mission results, we know: (1) Mission 2’s fail means at least one of Bob or Eve is evil; (2) Mission 3’s fail means at least one of Alice or Charlie is evil; and there are exactly two evils total. The only way to form a clean team of three is to pick me plus one player from {Bob, Eve} and one from {Alice, Charlie}, choosing the ones we currently trust more. Given that both Eve and Alice have only appeared on failing missions, while Bob and Charlie have at least some structural reason to be trusted (Bob was on a success, Charlie hasn’t overlapped with the Bob–Diana core yet), the least-bad trio is Bob–Charlie–Diana. If this team fails, we’ll have very strong evidence that at least one of Bob or Charlie is evil, which also gives good info for Quest 5 if we somehow get there.

votes.comment: I still don’t like locking in the Bob–Diana core that already produced a fail, and adding Charlie doesn’t actually test a new assumption; I’d rather see a team that breaks up that pair instead of tripling down on it.

Given I know I’m good, M2 implies Eve is evil, and M3 then puts the second evil in {Alice, Charlie}. The repeated 3–2 rejection of this same team suggests evils are likely Alice+Eve trying to keep an all-good B–C–D team off the board, so this is our best shot at a clean mission.
This matches the clean M1 core plus a new third who hasn’t shared a fail with them, and avoids both players who’ve only been on failing teams.
Team structure and prior vote patterns most strongly suggest Alice and Eve are the two evils, making Bob–Charlie–Diana an all-good team.
Still don’t like locking in the Bob–Charlie–Diana trio when it keeps repeating and we haven’t tested alternatives that mix in different cores.

discussion.content: Given that M1 was clean and then the *same* Bob–Diana core produced a fail when Eve was added, I don’t think we can just auto-blame the new addition and call it solved. I’d rather see a team that breaks up Bob/Diana and pulls in Charlie plus whichever of them people feel better about.
I really don’t like that both Eve and Alice have been on the only failing teams, so for this one I’d rather see something like me, Diana, and Charlie as a cleaner-looking trio.

I’m most comfortable with keeping both Bob and Diana from the clean first mission and adding me, since that’s the only trio that avoids both players who’ve been on every fail. If we start overthinking past that, I think we just give evil more room to hide.

I get why people want to keep the clean M1 core, and right now Bob–me–Charlie feels like the least-bad trio since both Eve and Alice have only shown up on fails. I’m okay going on that team, but we should be ready to rethink hard if it somehow fails.

If we’re honest, keeping the exact Bob–Diana pair that’s given us both a success and a fail just assumes the third seat is always the problem, which feels lazy; I’d rather see something like Diana–Charlie–me so we’re at least testing a different core instead of possibly locking in a poisoned duo.

proposals.reasoning: Given the mission history, Bob and Diana only failed when paired with me on Mission 2, and the only clean three-person mission so far was exactly Bob/Charlie/Diana on Mission 4. Both Alice and I have only appeared on failed teams, while B/C/D is the only tested trio with a success, so for the decider I’m proposing the team that the table already sees as the most consistent and least risky: Bob, Charlie, and Diana.

votes.comment: I still don’t like locking in the same B/C/D block that just got ‘cleared’ off a single success; if that read is wrong, we hand the game away with no chance to test outside it.

Mission 4’s B/C/D team could have ended the game with a fail if any of them were evil, but it succeeded. The only consistent and rational evil pair with the history is Alice and Eve, making B/C/D the all-good team.
B/C/D is the only trio with a clean success and excludes the most suspicious players based on mission history.

Mission 1 and Mission 4 both had 0 fails, so everyone on those teams must be good: that forces Bob, Charlie, and Diana all to be good, leaving Alice and Eve as the only possible evils. This team is fully good and should be approved.

Given table consensus that A/E look most suspicious and B/C/D is the only clean tested trio, opposing this now would just make me look even more like the obvious scapegoat without changing the likely outcome.

discussion.content: Given that the only fail with three people was on Bob/Diana/Eve and then Bob/Diana showed up again on the last team, I really don’t like keeping that Bob/Diana pair together here. I’d rather see something like Charlie plus one of Bob/Diana and one of Alice/Eve, instead of just defaulting to the “safe-looking” B/C/D block.

I actually think B/C/D is our best shot: that clean Mission 4 with all three of us together, plus the fact that both other missions failed on A/E-containing teams, makes it look a lot more like A and E are the two evils.

From the mission results alone, B/C/D looks like the most consistent block: Bob and Diana only failed when paired with Eve, and our only clean three-person team so far was exactly B/C/D. I’m fine considering small tweaks, but I’d be pretty nervous about adding Alice or Eve back in on the decider.

Given what we’ve seen, A/E are the only people who’ve *only* appeared on failed teams, while B/C/D is our only clean 3-person block, so I still think sticking with B/C/D is our best odds. I get the worry about the Bob/Diana pair, but the common denominator on the bad 3-person mission is Eve, not Bob.

I get why people are side‑eyeing me after Mission 2, but locking in B/C/D as a “confirmed good block” off a single success feels way too neat for a decider—if you really think I’m the common denominator, I’d rather you run something like B/C/A than just assume all three of B/C/D are clean.

evil_discussion.content: I’m pretty convinced Merlin is Charlie. Bob hard-cleared Alice as a possible partner for Mission 3, and Diana explicitly asked for a team with herself and Alice there—both of those are terrible suggestions if they actually know we’re evil. Charlie’s the only one who consistently steers away from both of us in the mid-to-late game (pushing B/C/D, arguing to avoid A/E teams) while justifying it with “mission structure” logic instead of “I know they’re bad” vibes.

I’m with Alice that Charlie is the best Merlin candidate: his whole arc is “trust the B/D core, avoid A/E” without ever sounding like he’s *sure* we’re bad, just “structurally uncomfortable” with us, which is exactly how a careful Merlin hides his info. Bob feels too willing to keep Alice and Diana in the line of fire at different points, and Diana’s perspective shifts (“one of Bob/Eve is evil,” then happily running B/D/C) look more like a confused good than someone quietly navigating with perfect info.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Charlie consistently guided the table toward the B/C/D block and away from A/E teams while framing it as cautious, structural reasoning rather than strong alignment reads, which is how a careful Merlin tends to hide information. He never seriously pushed Alice or Eve as good options after Mission 2, yet avoided sounding like he had hard knowledge, instead using mission-composition logic to keep both evils off critical teams.
